awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: WoU-MMA: Multi-Scale and Multi-Messenger Modeling of Jets in Active Galactic Nuclei
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1

Galaxies are vast collections of hundreds of billions of stars. In a minority of the galaxies their observed light is dominated by a single source: the supermassive black hole located at their very center. In these galaxies, the black hole feeds on material which turns into very hot ionized gas or plasma. Surprisingly, part of this material is ejected away from the black hole forming narrow beams of plasma that move at near the speed of light. These beams, when directed at Earth, make some of the brightest and extreme sources ever observed in the Universe.  The proposing team plans to perform the largest numerical simulations to study how matter falls from the vast scale of the galaxy into the tiny scale of the black hole and follow how the narrow fast beams of plasma form and shine as they propagate through the galaxy. The results from the numerical simulations will be publicly accessible through a user-friendly, interactive website. The user (scientist, teacher or high-school student) will be able to generate images of these beams in real-time and will thus be exposed to an exciting field of modern high-energy astrophysics.


Part 2

Recent detection by the IceCube Neutrino Observatory of a very high energy neutrino event coincident with multi-wavelength flaring of blazar TXS 0506+056 strongly suggests that blazars do not only produce high-energy photons but also ultra-high-energy cosmic rays and neutrinos. This exciting multi-messenger discovery motivates a detailed study of relativistic jet physics, to interpret this and upcoming multi-messenger observations of active galactic nuclei (AGN). The team proposes to perform multi-scale jet simulations that connect accretion physics, fluid dynamics, particle acceleration, and radiative transfer, to study the multi-wavelength polarized radiation signatures and neutrinos from AGN jets. The team plans to perform the largest to date general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations of AGN accretion and jets, extending from the black hole to the blazar emission zone. They will use first-principle kinetic plasma simulations to calculate particle acceleration in jet dissipation zones and build comprehensive multi-messenger polarized radiative transfer that includes all the relevant physics. In this way, the team can bridge the gap between first-principle modeling and multi-messenger observations, and advance the understanding of AGN jet physics responsible for multi-messenger emission. The team will disseminate the results to the public through an immersive website, train high-school students, and organize a summer school in compact objects for graduate students, where participants will work on theoretical and/or numerical problems at the forefront of the research field.

This award addresses/advances the goals of the Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At the centers of galaxies lie supermassive black holes with mass billions of times larger than that of our Sun. When these black hole capture gas from the host galaxy, they turn to bright sources of light while they are also observed to eject beams of ionized gas, or plasma, at a speed close to the speed of light. When the beam of plasma is directed towards Earth, it makes for some of the most bright and extremely variable astrophysical sources, called blazars. NSF is strongly invested in many large ground-based facilities aiming at the understanding of the physical processes that power these bright fireworks.  

Intellectual Merit: The project PI Giannios has lead a team of graduate students and postdocs studying the mechanisms responsible for the flares seen in blazars. They focused their studies on the extreme analogue of the process responsible for solar flares: that of magnetic reconnection and studies it with large-scale computer simulations. The team's findings were reported is a large number refereed publications where it was shown that magnetic reconnection (i) is a powerful mechanism in accelerating particles to very high energies and (ii) results in flaring production of light that resemples the observed patterns. This work paves the way in not only understanding the light signals from blazars but also exploring their potential in accelerating very high energy cosmic ray particles and producing energetic neutrinos. 

Broader Impcacts: The PI Giannios has introduced a new educational activity connected to the Doppler effect and the expansion of the Universe. This activity has been performed remotely three times over the past year;2 times each of which involved a group of about 20 high school students and once involviing high school educators (so that they repeat it in classroom settings). It consists of a presentation by the PI where the concept of the Doppler effect is highlighted for both sound and light. During the presentation, several breaks take place where the students are involved with hands-on, table-top activities where they can absorb these concepts. Several Purdue graduates and undergraduates assist with the break out rooms. Activity examples include: students have downloaded a smartphone app which allows them to measure the frequency of a sound source. They then move their smartphone periodically towards and away from a single-frequency source (sound generated from a laptop) and observed how the detected frequency is Doppler shifted periodically. The students also work in smaller groups to calculate examples of the Doppler effect for a sound and a light source. The light-source example discusses the shift on the lines of the spectrum of a galaxy. Ultimately, the activity has a discussion on the recession of the galaxies and the observed Hubble expansion of the Universe.
